text: Mihailo Josifović () also known as Vojvode Mikajle (Makedonski Brod, Ottoman Empire, 1870 - Makedonski Brod, Kingdom of Yugoslavia, April 1941) was a Serbian Chetnik voivode in Old Serbia during the time of the Macedonian struggle in the early part of 20th century.Дебърски глас, година 2, брой 29, 30 януари 1911, стр. 2. Три лире иначе нису представљале значајну суму. Отприлике је сума у складу са месечном надницом физичког радника. та плата је више била средство против могућих проневера него што је носила материјалну сигурност. He was killed by friendly fire before the start of World War II. ==Biography== Josifović was born in the village of Makedonski Brod in Poreč. He joined the Serbian Chetnik Organization in 1905 under the command of Rade Radivojević-Dušan. After the death of his commander in 1907, Mihailo Josifović served as voivode in 1908 until the Young Turk Revolution. From 1911 he was acting as the commander in Poreč with a nominal salary of three Turkish liras per month. When the Second Balkan War broke out in 1913, he defended Kičevo along with Vasilije Trbić, Boško Virjanac, Jovan Dolgač, and Dane Stojanović. After the war, he acquired 10 hectares of land in Makedonski Brod where he settled down to raise a family. ==Death== Vojvode Mikajle was killed at the beginning of World War II in an altercation with a sentry. He was killed by a guard, who asked Mikajle to lay down his weapon, unaware that he was a voivode (Duke). At the soldier's request to disarm, Mikajle kept defiantly approaching him with the question, "Do you know who I am?" A shot followed, killing him instantly. == References == Category:1870 births Category:1941 deaths Category:People from Poreč Category:People from Kosovo Vilayet Category:Serbian military personnel of the Balkan Wars Category:Serbian people of World War I Category:19th-century Serbian people Category:20th-century Serbian people
